questions.text: A 62-year-old hospitalized woman is evaluated for worsening skin lesions. She was admitted 6 days ago for total hip replacement surgery. The surgery was uncomplicated. She is receiving low-dose subcutaneous heparin for prophylaxis of DVT. O/E, there are several large purple/ black patches seen in the periumbilical region surrounded by erythema. Which of the following is true regarding heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT)?

choices.text: Type 1 is more common than type 2
Type 1 is due to antibodies against PF 4
HIT can lead to elevated fibrinogen levels
Type 2 occurs immediately after the initiation of heparin.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Type 1 is more common than type 2

Explanation: This patient, who underwent a Total hip replacement seven days ago on low-dose subcutaneous heparin, now has purple/black-colored skin necrosis at the abdominal injection site. This is a classic thrombotic complication of Heparin-induced thrombotic thrombocytopenia, commonly observed following the administration of unfractionated heparin.

 

Heparin Induced Thrombocytopenia is of 2 types:

 

HIT type 1

HIT type 2

Epidemiology

More common (Option A)

Less common

Timeline

Occurs immediately

Occurs 5 - 14 days after therapy(Option D)

Prognosis

Self-resolving

Can lead to life-threatening arterial or venous thrombosis

Pathogenesis

This occurs due to the platelet aggregating effects of heparin

Antibodies against PF4 that lead to platelet aggregation and thrombosis. (Option B)

 

  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia type 2 (HIT type 2) is an immune-mediated adverse reaction where antibodies form against complexes of heparin and platelet factor 4 (PF4).
  • These antibodies activate platelets, leading to their consumption and a pro-thrombotic state, resulting in both thrombocytopenia and an increased risk of thrombosis.
  • Fibrinogen levels usually decrease due to clot formation and consumption. (Option C).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with easy bruising and recurrent nosebleeds. Laboratory investigations reveal a prolonged aPTT. A mixing study is performed, and the aPTT corrects after mixing with normal plasma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Factor deficiency

Explanation: Mixing studies are done when there's a prolonged aPTT with normal BT and PT. This could be due to factor deficiency, like Factor VIII deficiency (hemophilia), or increased antibodies, as seen in Anti-phospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA), including lupus anticoagulant (LAC).

 

 

 

Platelet dysfunction(Option B)

Platelet dysfunction typically presents with symptoms such as easy bruising and recurrent nosebleeds. However, a prolonged aPTT typically indicates a defect in the coagulation cascade rather than platelet dysfunction.

 

Vitamin K deficiency(Option D)

vitamin K is crucial for synthesizing coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X. Its deficiency can lead to prolonged PT and aPTT. However, in this case, the aPTT corrects after mixing with normal plasma, indicating that clotting factors are present. Hence, vitamin K deficiency is less likely.

A 45-year-old male is admitted to the ICU following a road traffic accident. Upon arrival, he is hypotensive and tachycardic. Despite fluid resuscitation and transfusion of packed red blood cells, his condition deteriorates rapidly. Lab investigations show a sudden drop in platelet count and prolonged PT and aPTT. DIC is suspected. The thromboelastogram (TEG) graph is shown below:



 

Which of the following is correct?

choices.text: R time is more in Stage 1
K time is more in stage 2
Maximum amplitude is more in stage 2
Maximum amplitude is less in stage 1

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) K time is more in stage 2

Explanation: K time is more in stage 2 of DIC due to the increased time for the clot to reach firmness, as there is fibrinogen dysfunction in this stage.

 

Stages of DIC:

  • Stage 1- Hypercoagulable state with multiple clots being formed in vessels throughout the body. The graph shows decreased R time (Option A), decreased K time, higher maximum amplitude (Option C), and higher LY30 from subsequent fibrinolysis.
  • Stage 2- Widespread bleeding due to used-up clotting factors and platelets. The graph shows an increased R time, higher K time, lower maximum amplitude (Option D), and lower LY30.

questions.text: A 10 y/o boy presents with a history of recurrent nosebleeds and easy bruising since early childhood. O/E, there are multiple petechiae and ecchymoses on his skin. Laboratory investigations reveal normal platelet count but markedly decreased platelet aggregation. Bernard-Soulier Syndrome is suspected. Which of the following features would commonly be observed in platelet aggregometry for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) No aggregation with ristocetin

 

Explanation:

  • In platelet aggregometry, ristocetin enhances the binding of glycoprotein Ib/IX and von Willebrand factor, assessing platelet adhesion.
  • In Bernard-Soulier Syndrome (glycoprotein Ib/IX complex deficiency) and von Willebrand disease (vWF deficiency), platelet aggregation in response to ristocetin is typically abnormal (Option A).
    In contrast, aggregation responses to ADP, collagen, and epinephrine are typically normal (Options C and D).

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents with persistent bleeding from minor cuts and bruises since early childhood. On examination, there are multiple bruises and petechiae on her limbs. Lab investigations reveal normal platelet count but markedly decreased platelet aggregation. Glanzmann thrombasthenia is suspected. Which of the following agonists will be able to demonstrate decreased platelet aggregation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

Explanation:

  • In Glanzmann thrombasthenia, platelet aggregation is impaired due to dysfunctional glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. During platelet aggregometry, ADP, epinephrine, and collagen are added to stimulate platelet aggregation by increasing the binding of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa.
  • However, in Glanzmann thrombasthenia, platelets fail to aggregate in response to these agonists due to dysfunctional glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Thus, Option D, "All of the above," is correct.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a history of easy bruising and recurrent nosebleeds. Laboratory investigations reveal normal platelet count but prolonged bleeding time. A Platelet aggregometry test is performed, showing a decrease in light transmission. What is the most likely interpretation of the platelet aggregometry results in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) No platelet aggregation

Explanation: The decrease in light transmission observed during platelet aggregometry indicates no platelet aggregation.

  • This test measures platelet adhesion, secretion, and aggregation by passing light through platelet-rich plasma.
  • Initially, light transmission is reduced as the cells are dispersed through plasma.
  • Upon the addition of agonists like ristocetin, ADP, epinephrine, and collagen, platelet aggregation occurs, creating clots that allow light to transmit (Option A). Therefore, a decrease in light transmission signifies the absence of platelet aggregates. (Option B)

 

 

Serum sodium (Option C):

Serum sodium levels are not directly assessed or measured during platelet aggregometry.

 

 Increase in plasma fibrinogen (Option D):

Platelet aggregometry primarily assesses platelet function and aggregation, not plasma fibrinogen levels. Therefore, a decrease in light transmission during the test is unrelated to increased plasma fibrinogen.

questions.text: A 35-year-old mother underwent a C-section. On post-op day 1, she complains of shortness of breath and bleeding from catheter sites. Her vitals are unstable. Which of the following statements is false concerning her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) PT and APTT are normal

Explanation:

This 35-year-old mother just delivered one day ago and is now having symptoms of Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

  • DIC is classified as an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombo-hemorrhagic illness characterized by excessive coagulation activation and microvascular thrombi formation.
  • Common causes include sepsis, significant trauma, malignant neoplasms, and complications during pregnancy.
  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia (AML M3) and adenocarcinomas of the stomach, colon, pancreas, and lung are frequently associated with DIC. (Option B)
  • DIC is triggered by two main mechanisms:
    • Extensive endothelial cell damage and
    • Release of tissue factor or other procoagulants into the bloodstream.
  • Additionally, widespread endothelial damage can result from the deposition of antigen-antibody complexes, extremes in temperature, or infections like meningococci and rickettsiae (Option D).
  • Signs and symptoms of DIC may include hemorrhage due to depleted hemostatic components, tissue hypoxia, and infarction due to microthrombi, or both.
  • Diagnosis: ↓ platelet count, ↓ fibrinogen levels; ↑ PT, ↑ aPTT, and ↑ fibrin breakdown products, especially D-dimers (Option C).

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a history of bloody diarrhea followed by pallor, fatigue, and reduced urine output. Laboratory investigations reveal anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated serum creatinine. A peripheral blood smear is done and is given below. What is the most likely cause of this child’s diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) O157:H7

Explanation:

This child with symptoms of bloody diarrhea followed by symptoms of renal failure, anemia, and thrombocytopenia has Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS)


Types of HUS and its risk factors:

 

Both types of HUS lead to endothelial injury, resulting in thrombus formation.

The characteristic features include renal involvement, hemolytic anemia with schistocytes, thrombocytopenia, and elevated bleeding time.

 

Defect in ADAM-TS 13 (Option B):

A defect in ADAM TS 13 (breaks multimers of VWF) is seen in Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP). It usually presents as a pentad of fever, thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, temporary neurologic impairments, and renal failure.

 

Mutation in TGF-beta (Option C):

 

  • .Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome also known as hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia(HHT) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple AV malformations in viscera and mucocutaneous structures such as the lips,tongue,buccal mucosa and fingertips.

 

Prosthetic valves (Option D):

Prosthetic heart valves can cause macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia due to mechanical stress, where red blood cells fracture from increased blood flow around the valve. The spleen removes damaged cells that do not hemolyse in circulation through extravascular hemolysis. However, this is not a specific risk factor for HUS.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with recurrent episodes of spontaneous bleeding into his joints. Laboratory tests reveal a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) and reduced factor VIII levels. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hemophilia A

Explanation: This 5-year-old boy has Hemophilia A, caused by a factor VIII deficiency. Factor VIII is a necessary cofactor for factor IX in the coagulation cascade.

Hemophilia is an X-linked recessive disorder. Hence, only males are affected.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of occasional dizziness and palpitations in crowded spaces. He is an executive who travels frequently and reports high-stress levels at work.

Labs: Hb= 14.0

Platelets = 80,000

Leukocytes = 7,200

RBCs= 5 million

Peripheral smear shows a reduced platelet count without clumping or malignant cells. Which of the following is the most appropriate next test for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) HIV antibody test

Explanation:

Isolated thrombocytopenia without anemia or leukopenia suggests Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP), diagnosed after excluding other causes. Thrombocytopenia may occur in chronic HIV infection; thus, HIV and hepatitis C testing are essential. ITP is a diagnosis of exclusion, requiring exclusion of other causes of thrombocytopenia.

 

Features

Chronic ITP

Often follows viral infections

Can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to SLE, HIV, CLL

normal PT and aPTT, ↑BT

EBV virus titers (Option A):

EBV virus titers are useful for diagnosing infectious mononucleosis. Patients with infectious mononucleosis usually present with fatigue, sore throat, fever, palatal petechiae, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. Labs show lymphocytosis and possible thrombocytopenia. This patient does not have findings of infectious mononucleosis.

 

Rapid plasma reagin test (Option B):

It is a non-troponemal antigen test used to screen for syphilis. However, syphilis is not associated with thrombocytopenia.

 

Schilling test (Option C):

Schilling test determines if vitamin B12 deficiency is due to pernicious anemia or a malabsorption syndrome. It is not used to diagnose ITP.

questions.text: A 14-year-old adolescent presents with recurrent episodes of unexplained swelling and pain following minor injuries or physical activity. Upon examination, there are signs of localized swelling and tenderness. Lab investigations reveal normal platelet counts and bleeding time, but clotting times are prolonged. Which symptom would strongly suggest a coagulation defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hemarthrosis

Explanation:

Coagulation factor abnormalities, or defects in secondary hemostasis, may manifest as bleeding into soft tissues like muscles or joints. Hemarthrosis, characterized by bleeding into joints following minor trauma, is a specific feature associated with hemophilia.

 

Clinical manifestation

Platelet disorders

Coagulation disorders

Bleeding site

Mucous membranes

Muscles and joints

Presentation

Superficial bleeds like Petechia , purpura, mucosal bleeds; multiple sites

Deep tissue bleeds like Hematoma , intracranial bleeds (most dangerous ) , joint bleeds/ hemarthroses (most common); localized

May be delayed at onset

Petechiae(Option A):

Petechiae (minute 1 to 2-mm hemorrhages) arise due to a defect in platelet function. They occur as pinpoint hemorrhages in the dependent areas where the capillary pressure is higher.

 

Purpura (Option B):

Purpura are slightly larger than petechiae (>3 mm) and can be palpable. They are often seen in conditions like Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

 

Ecchymoses(Option C):

Ecchymoses, or bruises, are 1 to 2-cm hemorrhages. The volume of blood that has been extravasated in purpura and ecchymoses may be sufficient to form a palpable mass of blood called a hematoma.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of frequent nosebleeds and heavy menstrual periods. She reports prolonged bleeding after minor cuts and has noticed easy bruising. On physical examination, multiple small bruises are on her arms and legs. Which of the following tests is most likely to be abnormal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bleeding Time (BT)

Explanation:

  • The symptoms described—frequent nosebleeds, heavy menstrual periods, prolonged bleeding after minor cuts, and easy bruising—are characteristic of a primary hemostasis disorder, which involves platelet function.
  • The Bleeding Time (BT) test assesses the function of platelets and their ability to form a primary hemostatic plug. Normal BT is 2 to 9 minutes and is prolonged when there is a defect in platelet function.


 

Clotting time (CT) (Option B):

The clotting time (CT) reflects the time needed for clot formation rather than platelet function. Normal CT: 8-15 mins.

 

 

Prothrombin time (PT) (Option C):

  • Prothrombin time is used to assess both extrinsic and common coagulation pathways.
  • Deficits or dysfunctions of factors 1, 2, 5, 7, or 10 can cause a prolonged prothrombin time (PT). Normal PT: 11-16 secs. 
  • INR = PT of patient / PT of a normal person.

 

Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) (Option D):

  • Activated partial prothrombin time is used to study intrinsic and common coagulation processes. Normal aPTT: 25-30 secs.
  • Deficits or dysfunctions of factors 12, 11, 9, 8, 10, 5, 2, 1 or interfering antiphospholipid antibodies can all prolong the aPTT.

questions.text: A 2-week-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his parents because of prolonged bleeding from the umbilical stump. The parents report that the bleeding started soon after the umbilical cord fell off and has not stopped despite applying pressure. Laboratory tests show normal Prothrombin Time (PT), Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT), and platelet count. Which of the following deficiencies is most likely causing the prolonged bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Factor XIII

Explanation:

  • Factor XIII is crucial for maintaining clot stability and promoting fibrin polymer cross-linking, ensuring effective hemostasis.
  • Its deficiency can lead to prolonged bleeding from the umbilical stump in neonates, as seen in this case. Other symptoms include severe menstrual bleeding, hemarthrosis, repeated early pregnancy loss, and delayed postoperative bleeding.
  • Unlike other factors, Factor XIII deficiency does not affect BT, CT, PT, aPTT, or platelet count. Diagnosis is confirmed with a urea clot solubility test, in which the clot dissolves if Factor XIII is deficient.

 

 

 Factor VIII deficiency (Option A):

  • Hemophilia A, or Factor VIII deficiency is an X-linked disorder, characterized by elevated aPTT and causes deep tissue and joint bleeding.
  • Von Willebrand factor (vWF) protects Factor VIII from degradation, and its deficiency can lead to reduced Factor VIII levels, resulting in a condition called pseudohemophilia.

 

Factor IV deficiency (Option C):

Factor IV (calcium) is essential for the coagulation cascade, activating Factor X in intrinsic and extrinsic pathways. However, calcium deficiency is extremely rare and not associated with umbilical stump bleeding; it typically causes widespread bleeding.

 

Factor IX deficiency (Option D):

Factor IX deficiency (Hemophilia B or Christmas disease) is an X-linked recessive disorder affecting the intrinsic pathway, causing elevated aPTT with normal PT. Like Hemophilia A, it primarily leads to deep tissue and joint bleeding.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with a history of recurrent episodes of uncontrolled bleeding from minor injuries and easy bruising. Lab investigations reveal prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). Considering a potential vitamin K deficiency, which specific clotting factors should be evaluated to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Stable factor

Explanation:

In the context of a potential vitamin K deficiency, clotting factors synthesized in the liver and dependent on vitamin K should be evaluated.

  • Factors II (Prothrombin), VII (Stable factor), IX (Christmas factor), X (Stuart-Prower factor), and Protein C depend on vitamin K for synthesis in the liver.
  • Vitamin K deficiency leads to reduced carboxylation of glutamate residues on clotting factors impairing blood clotting.

 

Factors III (Tissue thromboplastin), V (Labile factor), and XII (Hageman factor) are not vitamin K-dependent factors (Options A, B, and C)

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with easy bruising, heavy menstrual bleeding, and prolonged bleeding after cuts and dental extraction. Lab tests show normal platelet counts but impaired platelet function. Which of the following substances, primarily released from alpha granules, might be deficient in this patient's platelets?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) P-selectin

Explanation:

P-selectin, primarily released from platelet alpha granules, plays a crucial role in platelet aggregation and adhesion. Its deficiency leads to easy bruising and prolonged bleeding.

questions.text: A 22 y/o woman arrives at the clinic complaining of heavy menstrual flow and recurrent nosebleeds. Upon physical inspection, her arms and legs have several minor bruises. Coagulation studies show high BT, APTT, and normal PT. She is diagnosed with von Willibrand disease. Which type of vWD shows a decrease in binding between VWF and Gp 1b/9?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B)Type 2a

Explanation:

  • Von Willebrand disease is the most common inherited bleeding disorder.
  • Clinically and molecularly, von Willebrand disease is heterogeneous, below are 3 identified kinds, each with a variety of phenotypes;

 

vWD type 1 (Option A)

vWD Type 2

vWD Type 3 (Option D)
  • Autosomal dominant.
  • The most common type.
  • Mild to moderate vWF deficiency.
  • Quantitative defect.
  • point substitutions prevent the vWF protein from maturing or cause it to leave the plasma quickly
  • Autosomal dominant.
  • Qualitative defect.


Types: 2A, 2B, 2M, 2N

  • 2A (Most common) - Decrease in binding between vWF and Gp1b/9 (Option B) missense mutations cause faulty multimer formation → the most active forms of vWF, i.e. large- and intermediate-sized multimers are absent.
  • 2B - Increase in binding between vWF and Gp1b/9 (Option C)
  • 2M - VWF dependant platelet adhesion is decreased. There is impairment of VWF binding to platelets. Type 2M VWD typically has mild to moderate mucocutaneous bleeding
  • 2N - There is marked decline in the binding affinity for factor VIII. The level of factor VIII is lower when compared to the VWF:Ag. This led to misdiagnosis as haemophilia A
  • Autosomal recessive.
  • Quantitative defect.
  • produced by frameshift mutations or deletions affecting both alleles (autosomal recessive), which produce little or no vWF.
  • Factor VIII levels are also lowered because vWF stabilizes factor VIII in the blood, and the resulting bleeding condition is severe.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is diagnosed with von Willebrand Disease (vWD) after presenting with frequent nosebleeds and prolonged bleeding after minor cuts. Laboratory tests reveal a defect in the von Willebrand factor (vWF). Which of the following is also involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gp1b-IX

Explanation: Gp1b-IX is a membrane complex in platelets that facilitates binding to the von Willebrand Factor, which is defective/deficient in von Willebrand disease.

 

gpIIb-IIIa (Option B):

This glycoprotein complex is crucial for platelet aggregation, the final step in primary hemostasis. It binds fibrinogen and von Willebrand factor (vWF), aiding in the formation of platelet plugs. However, defects in gpIIb-IIIa are not associated with von Willebrand Disease (vWD).

 

 Factor IX (Option C):

Factor IX (or Christmas factor) is a vitamin K-dependent clotting factor, part of the intrinsic clotting pathway. Factor IX deficiency is known as Hemophilia B, an X-linked recessive disorder.

 

Factor XIII (Option D):

Factor XIII stabilises fibrin by cross linking and deficiency leads to severe bleeding.
